title: Police puzzled by ‘flux capacitor’
text:
Email a friend 
BACK to the Future Day mania has officially crossed the thin blue line. 
In honour of today, that most significant day that Marty McFly and Doc Brown crash-land the DeLorean into 2015 in Back to the Future II , Queensland police have issued a spoof media statement about a bizarre car crash that was being investigated by its fictional Mount Isa Hoverboard Unit. 
According to the statement, Hoverboard Unit officers were called to a crash this morning involving a silver sedan that had ploughed into a power pole near the cinema on Mt Isa’s (also fictional) Rodeo Drive. 
“When questioned what speed he was doing, the driver stated that he was doing 88 miles per hour,” police said in the statement. 
“A 17-year-old man was charged and was in possession of a licence which expired over 30 years ago.” 
Police said investigations into the mysterious vehicle were ongoing, as were their inquiries about “what a flux capacitor is”. The Mt Isa police Hoverboard Unit were on the case. Picture: QLD Police Source: Supplied 
The statement goes on to report that the Mount Isa Cinema suffered a loss of power to the building as a result of the crash. 
Owner Jodi Saunders told police the driver got out of the crashed car and asked for a Pepsi. 
“He also wanted to know when we would be playing Jaws 19 ,” Ms Saunders reportedly told officers. 
The damage to the power pole also caused a power outage to the area, much to the chagrin of the city mayor — not busboy-turned-politician Goldie Wilson, but actual Mt Isa mayor Tony McGrady. 
According to the police report, Cr McGrady attributed the power outage to damage sustained to the town clock, which had stopped working. The prime suspect in the sedan crash. Source: Supplied Pepsi Perfect in a scene from the 1989 film Back To The Future Part II 2. Source: Supplied 
“We have repairs underway to save the clock tower,” the mayor said. 
Police in South Australia have also jumped in on the fun, claiming to have arrested a group of youths “involved in a hoverboard chase and altercation at the Courthouse Mall”. 
“The gang, conspicuously dressed in upcycled Tupperware containers, wrist-guards and breastplates were seen chasing a teenage male from Café 80s adjacent the Holomax Theatre on Main Street,” the statement read. 
The police then said the youths were ultimately arrested for crimes against fashion. 
Thanks for the LOLs, police.
